comments.text:  portable_timegm does the same as C._mkgmtime, but unlike it,
 can work with dates before the Unix epoch of 1970-01-01 .
 days_from_unix_epoch - return the number of days since the Unix epoch 1970-01-01.
 A detailed description of the algorithm here is in:
 Note that function will return negative values for days before 1970-01-01.

contents.content: fn days_from_unix_epoch(year int, month int, day int) int
contents.name: days_from_unix_epoch

comments.text:  Time contains various time units for a point in time.
 operator `<` returns true if provided time is less than time
 operator `==` returns true if provided time is equal to time
 add returns a new time with the given duration added.
 add_days returns a new time struct with an added number of days.
 add_seconds returns a new time struct with an added number of seconds.
 as_local returns the exact same time, as the receiver `t`, but with its .is_local field set to true.
 as_utc returns the exact same time, as the receiver `t`, but with its .is_local field set to false.
 clean returns a date string in a following format:
 - a date string in "HH:mm" format (24h) for current day
 - a date string in "MMM D HH:mm" format (24h) for date of current year
 - a date string formatted with format function for other dates
 clean12 returns a date string in a following format:
 - a date string in "hh:mm" format (12h) for current day
 - a date string in "MMM D hh:mm" format (12h) for date of current year
 - a date string formatted with format function for other dates
 custom_format returns a date with custom format
 println(time.now().custom_format('MMMM Mo YY N kk:mm:ss A')) // output like: January 1st 22 AD 13:45:33 PM
 day_of_week returns the current day as an integer.
 days_from_unix_epoch - return the number of days since the Unix epoch 1970-01-01.
 A detailed description of the algorithm here is in:
 Note that method will return negative values for days before 1970-01-01.
 ddmmy returns a date string in "DD.MM.YYYY" format.
 debug returns detailed breakdown of time (`Time{ year: YYYY month: MM day: dd hour: HH: minute: mm second: ss nanosecond: nanos unix: unix }`)
 format returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm" format (24h).
 format_rfc3339 returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.123Z" format (24 hours, see https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3339.html)
 RFC3339 is an Internet profile, based on the ISO 8601 standard for for representation of dates and times using the Gregorian calendar.
 It is intended to improve consistency and interoperability, when representing and using date and time in Internet protocols.
 format_rfc3339_nano returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.123456789Z" format (24 hours, see https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc3339.html)
 format_ss returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss" format (24h).
 format_ss_micro returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss.123456" format (24h).
 format_ss_milli returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss.123" format (24h).
 format_ss_nano returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss.123456789" format (24h).
 get_fmt_time_str returns a date string with specified

children.content: fn (t Time) get_fmt_date_str(fmt_dlmtr FormatDelimiter, fmt_date FormatDate) string
children.name: get_fmt_date_str

comments.text:  get_fmt_str returns a date string with specified FormatDelimiter,

children.content: fn (t Time) get_fmt_str(fmt_dlmtr FormatDelimiter, fmt_time FormatTime, fmt_date FormatDate) string
children.name: get_fmt_str

comments.text:  get_fmt_time_str returns a date string with specified FormatTime type.
 hhmm returns a date string in "HH:mm" format (24h).
 hhmm12 returns a date string in "hh:mm" format (12h).
 hhmmss returns a date string in "HH:mm:ss" format (24h).
 is_utc returns true, when the receiver `t` is a UTC time, and false otherwise.
 local - return the time `t`, converted to the currently active local timezone
 local_to_utc converts the receiver `t` to the corresponding UTC time, if it contains local time.
 If the receiver already does contain UTC time, it returns it unchanged.
 long_weekday_str returns the current day as a string.
 md returns a date string in "MMM D" format.
 relative returns a string representation of the difference between t
 relative_short returns a string saying how long ago a time occurred as follows:
 0-30 seconds: `"now"`; 30-60 seconds: `"1m"`; anything else is rounded to the
 nearest minute, hour, day, or year
 smonth returns the month name abbreviation.
 str returns the time in the same format as `parse` expects ("YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss").
 strftime returns the formatted time using `strftime(3)`
 unix_time returns the UNIX time with second resolution.
 unix_time_micro returns the UNIX time with microsecond resolution.
 unix_time_milli returns the UNIX time with millisecond resolution.
 unix_time_nano returns the UNIX time with nanosecond resolution.
 This is just a TEMPORARY function for cookies and their expire dates
 utc_to_local converts the receiver `u` to the corresponding local time, if it contains UTC time.
 If the receiver already does contain local time, it returns it unchanged.
 weekday_str returns the current day as a string 3 letter abbreviation.
 year_day returns the current day of the year as an integer.
 ymmdd returns a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD" format.

contents.content:
struct Time {
pub:
	year       int
	month      int
	day        int
	hour       int
	minute     int
	second     int
	nanosecond int
	unix       i64
	is_local   bool // used to make time.now().local().local() == time.now().local()
	//
	microsecond int @[deprecated: 'use t.nanosecond / 1000 instead'; deprecated_after: '2023-08-05']
}
contents.name: Time

comments.text:  date_from_days_after_unix_epoch - convert number of `days` after the unix epoch 1970-01-01, to a Time.
 Only the year, month and day of the returned Time will be set, everything else will be 0.
 parse_rfc3339 returns the time from a date string in RFC 3339 datetime format.
 See also https://ijmacd.github.io/rfc3339-iso8601/ for a visual reference of
 the differences between ISO-8601 and RFC 3339.
 parse returns the time from a date string in "YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss" format.
 parse_format parses the string `s`, as a custom `format`, containing the following specifiers:
 parse_iso8601 parses the ISO 8601 time format yyyy-MM-ddTHH:mm:ss.dddddd+dd:dd as local time.
 The fraction part is difference in milli seconds, and the last part is offset from UTC time.
 Remarks: not all of ISO 8601 is supported; checks and support for leapseconds should be added.
 parse_rfc2822 returns the time from a date string in RFC 2822 datetime format.
 TimeParseError represents a time parsing error.

contents.name: TimeParseError

comments.text:  StopWatch is used to measure elapsed time.
 start starts the stopwatch. If the timer was paused, it continues counting.
 restart restarts the stopwatch. If the timer was paused, it restarts counting.
 stop stops the timer, by setting the end time to the current time.
 pause resets the `start` time and adds the current elapsed time to `elapsed`.
 elapsed returns the Duration since the last start call

contents.content:
struct StopWatch {
mut:
	elapsed u64
pub mut:
	start u64
	end   u64
}
contents.name: StopWatch

comments.text:  new_stopwatch initializes a new StopWatch with the current time as start.
 C.timeval represents a C time value.

contents.name: C.timeval

comments.text:  now returns the current local time.
 utc returns the current UTC time.
 new_time returns a time struct with the calculated Unix time.
 ticks returns the number of milliseconds since the UNIX epoch.
 On Windows ticks returns the number of milliseconds elapsed since system start.
 days returns the duration as a floating point number of days.
 debug returns a detailed breakdown of the Duration, as: 'Duration: - 50days, 4h, 3m, 7s, 541ms, 78us, 9ns'
 hours returns the duration as a floating point number of hours.
 microseconds returns the duration as an integer number of microseconds.
 milliseconds returns the duration as an integer number of milliseconds.
 minutes returns the duration as a floating point number of minutes.
 nanoseconds returns the duration as an integer number of nanoseconds.
 The following functions return floating point numbers because it's common to
 consider all of them in sub-one intervals
 seconds returns the duration as a floating point number of seconds.
 some *nix system functions (e.g. `C.poll()`, C.epoll_wait()) accept an `int`
 value as *timeout in milliseconds* with the special value `-1` meaning "infinite"
 The unsigned zero year for internal calculations.
 Must be 1 mod 400, and times before it will not compute correctly,
 but otherwise can be changed at will.

contents.content:
enum FormatTime {
	hhmm12
	hhmm24
	hhmmss12
	hhmmss24
	hhmmss24_milli
	hhmmss24_micro
	hhmmss24_nano
	no_time
}
contents.name: FormatTime

contents.content:
enum FormatDate {
	ddmmyy
	ddmmyyyy
	mmddyy
	mmddyyyy
	mmmd
	mmmdd
	mmmddyy
	mmmddyyyy
	no_date
	yyyymmdd
	yymmdd
}
contents.name: FormatDate

contents.content:
enum FormatDelimiter {
	dot
	hyphen
	slash
	space
	no_delimiter
}
contents.name: FormatDelimiter

comments.text:  since returns the time duration elapsed since a given time.
 day_of_week returns the current day of a given year, month, and day,

contents.content: fn day_of_week(y int, m int, d int) int

comments.text:  is_leap_year checks if a given a year is a leap year.
 days_in_month returns a number of days in a given month.
 offset returns time zone UTC offset in seconds.

struct C.tm {
	tm_year int
	tm_mon  int
	tm_mday int
	tm_hour int
	tm_min  int
	tm_sec  int
}
contents.name: C.tm
C._FILETIME

comments.text:  in most systems, these are __quad_t, which is an i64

contents.name: C.timespec

comments.text:  sys_mono_now returns a *monotonically increasing time*, NOT a time adjusted for daylight savings, location etc.
 sleep makes the calling thread sleep for a given duration (in nanoseconds).
 unix returns a time struct from an Unix timestamp (number of seconds since 1970-01-01)
 unix2 returns a Time struct, given an Unix timestamp in seconds, and a microsecond value

contents.content: fn unix2(abs i64, microsecond int) Time
contents.name: unix2
